dmca.title: Requesting removal of copyrighted images
dmca.body:
Please see below and act accordingly.

-----Original Message-----
From: Hunter Boyle [mailto:hunterboyle2@yahoo.com] 
Posted At: Friday, August 25, 2006 2:02 PM
Posted To: Copyright
Conversation: Requesting removal of copyrighted images
Subject: Requesting removal of copyrighted images


ATTN: Andrea Almeida, Associate General Counsel

Hello Andrea,

My name is Hunter Boyle. I'm writing per ThePlanet.com's instructions
concerning copyright notifications. I will try to address the six
requirements as posted on the site, regarding images for which I hold
the exclusive copyright.

Some background info: I photographed a woman in 2002, with a release and
binding agreement stating I reserved all rights to usage. She posted the
images on a now-defunct site formerly hosted by ThePlanet.com. That site
was ezedcard.com. Because the site is now down, the woman cannot log in
to remove the images from that old account. (She has been very helpful
in removing other images from another site she'd also posted them on.)

As the copyright holder, I'd like to try and have the images removed
from the cache of Google's Image search. I called ThePlanet.com to talk
with a tech support rep to handle this, but was forwarded to the page on
copyright issues.

Specifically, what I'd like your/ThePlanet's help with is clearing out
my images from the cache of the following URLs:
* http://www.ezedcard.com/zipporahnaomi/pc6.jpg
* http://www.ezedcard.com/zipporahnaomi/pr6.jpg
* http://www.ezedcard.com/zipporahnaomi/pt6.jpg

* http://www.ezedcard.com/zipporahnaomi/pc7.jpg
* http://www.ezedcard.com/zipporahnaomi/pr7.jpg
* http://www.ezedcard.com/zipporahnaomi/pt7.jpg

* http://www.ezedcard.com/zipporahnaomi/pc9.jpg
* http://www.ezedcard.com/zipporahnaomi/pr9.jpg
* http://www.ezedcard.com/zipporahnaomi/pt9.jpg

While clicking these URLs doesn't bring up the images, the page that
shows up won't allow Google to remove the images from its cache index.
In order for that to happen, the URLs must show a 404 error message or
completely dead link. It can then be removed with a request to Google
via its Webmaster help section.

With your approval and assistance, I'd like to request ThePlanet.com
allow these dead URLs to show an actual 404 error message, rather than
the placeholder page, so I can request removal from Google's index.

There are a few simple ways to accomplish this, including:
* a robots.txt file in the "/zipporahnaomi" folder -- which I could
provide to the tech support rep
* removing the current "Test Page" default landing page and allowing the
natural 404 error message to show.

The first method (using a robots.txt file) is preferred because it works
much faster with Google. I can email that file to you and tech support
as soon as possible with your approval. It will not affect any other
files on the web server. It simply tells Google's imagebot to go away
without indexing the images in the specified folder (/zipporahnaomi -
now down anyway, along with the rest of the ezedcard.com site)

Please let me know if this solution would be agreeable, as I have the
consent of the woman who originally posted the images, the full rights
to my copyrights. Thanks very much for your consideration in this
matter.

I believe I've hit all six requirements for a request and look forward
to hearing from you. I can be reached at:

Hunter Boyle
1000 Conestoga Rd. #C-357
Bryn Mawr, PA  19010
215-906-3423 (cell)
hb@hunterboyle.com

P.S. Since the URLs mentioned above are already dead, you can see the
images I'm referring to in Google's Image search cache at:
http://images.google.com/images?hl=en&lr=&safe=off&q=+site:www.ezedcard.
com+%22hunter+boyle%22


===

To be effective, a Notification of Claimed Infringement must meet the
following requirements:

    * It must include the following:
         1. A physical or electronic signature of a person ("Complaining
Party") authorized to act on behalf of the owner of an exclusive right
that is claimed to be infringed;
         2. Identification of the copyrighted work claimed to have been
infringed, or if multiple copyrighted works at a single online site are
covered by a single notification, a representative list of such works at
that site;
         3. Identification of the material that is claimed to be
infringing or to be the subject of infringing activity and that is to be
removed or access to which is to be disabled, and information reasonably
sufficient to permit the service provider to locate the material;
         4. Information reasonably sufficient to permit the service
provider to contact the Complaining Party, such as an address, telephone
number, and, if available, an electronic mail address at which the
complaining party may be contacted;
         5. A statement that the Complaining Party has a good faith
belief that use of the material in the manner complained of is not
authorized by the copyright owner, its agent, or the law; and
         6. A statement that the information in the notification is
accurate, and under penalty of perjury, that the Complaining Party is
authorized to act on behalf of the owner of an exclusive right that is
allegedly infringed.


__________________________________________________
